# Implementing marketplace mint/buy/sell transactions on Cardano using Kuber API

Welcome to the kuber, an API/Haskell library for easily constructing transactions for Cardano.
Here you will find a tutorial that describes the features for constructing transactions using kuber API and submitting it using NAMI wallet for now.

Kuber is an open-source library and easy-to-use API created by Dquadrant which makes it easy for Cardano developers to compose complex EUTxO transactions. https://github.com/dQuadrant/kuber

We are using cardano testnet and kuber playground hosted in https://dquadrant.github.io/kuber/

### **Part 1 - Minting a Cardano Native Token with metadata using kuber playground and NAMI wallet**

**Nami wallet**

Kuber playground integrates with Nami wallet to sign transactions, so you have to download
the Nami wallet extension from here https://namiwallet.io/ for your browser. Follow the
instructions of Nami to create your wallet. Once you have Nami wallet installed and you
created a wallet you have to go to Settings Network and activate Testnet since the Kuber
playground interacts with the harforked Vasil Cardano testnet.

Once you have activated the testnet you need some tADA (test ADA) from the faucet,
https://testnets.cardano.org/en/testnets/cardano/tools/faucet/

To receive tADA you need the wallet address of your Nami wallet you like to use with Kuber,
you can press on Receive and copy your wallet address.
On the testnet faucet page past your wallet address in the Address field and complete the
ReCAPTCHA and push Request Funds. A few moments after you pressed the button
Request Funds you should receive 1000 tADA on your Nami wallet address.

One more step to go since in this tutorial we are going to interact with smart contracts, so we
have to pay a collateral for this. In Nami wallet go to Collateral and make the specified
payment from your wallet address on which you received your tADA.


**Mint a Cardano Native Token**

In order to mint a Cardano Native Token we have to follow the CIP-25 NFT metadata
standard https://cips.cardano.org/cips/cip25/.

We are using the CDDL V2 standard, this is the new standard after the Vasil hardfork was
completed on Cardano testnet.

To mint a native token you need a unique key hash, a unique policy id and asset name in
raw format.


**Key Hash**

Kuber provides a utility to generate a unique Key hash on the basis of your Nami wallet
address. Copy your Nami wallet address by pushing Receive and copy and go to Utilities in
the right top menu of the Kuber playground and choose Compute PubKey Hash.

Paste your Nami wallet address in the Address field and push the Get Hash Key button to
generate a unique Key hash required to Mint a Cardano Native Token.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183341834-260acf22-4c34-4647-a463-2fa9cb65ca38.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183341888-a8f2bc6d-618f-40ac-906b-873972f7a0d4.png)

Copy the generated Key hash to be used in your metadata according to the CIP-25
specification.

**Asset name**

To generate an asset name in raw format we are using
https://onlineutf8tools.com/convert-utf8-to-bytes, make use of disable spaces between bytes
and in the utf8 field we are typing our asset name, for example Kuber token.
Now copy the result from the bytes field, in the above example the outcome is
4b7562657220746f6b656e and use it in your metadata according to the CIP-25
specification.�

Both the asset name in raw format and text format conform CIP-25 should be the same.


**Digital representation of the Cardano native token (image)**

To represent the Cardano native token we need to upload an image to IPFS (InterPlanetair
File System).

We are using https://anarkrypto.github.io/upload-files-to-ipfs-from-browser-panel/public/ for
simplicity in uploading the image and receiving the hash for the image after upload to be
used in the metadata.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183342204-d28da185-7705-414b-bb13-b464bf8bb45e.png)

Next we copy the hash, in this example QmYNeud6Qci8jkWCJYoVHXojvt8e4pBXDhB7UDncSE8Lvi
and use it to define our metadata file.


**Policy Id**

To mint a native token we need a unique Policy id that needs to be generated on the basis of
a policy script. Below you will find an example of such a script that contains the keyHash we
generated before for our Nami wallet.

```json
{
  "type": "all",
  "scripts": [
    {
      "keyHash": "64b1b102380752d1f1d16b86e77129c68b69a97cb684b1dd5a0fe8df",
      "type": "sig"
    },
    {
        "type": "before",
        "slot": 65163944
    }
  ]
}
```
Further it specifies a slot number and type. In this case the Cardano Native Token is
expected to be minted before slot 65163944. And cannot be minted after the slot.

You can find the current slot on testnet either via testnet.cardanoscan.io or via the
cardano-cli.

Below an example of the testnet slot to be found on https://testnet.cardanoscan.io and
https://explorer.cardano-testnet.iohkdev.io/en for testnet.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183342939-1357df7c-d7b2-4e8b-a56f-3c00a872fa4b.png)

Cardano-cli command on testnet to receive the current slot:

```bash
cardano-cli query tip --testnet-magic 1097911063
```

You have to make sure that you have enough time to mint your Cardano Native Token, let’s
assume that the current slot is 65163344, by defining 65163944 would give you 600/60 = 10
minutes time to mint your Cardano Native Token.

Next we are using the policy script to generate a unique Policy id via Kuber. Go to Utilities
right top corner of the Kuber playground and choose Compute ScriptHash and paste your
policy script into the field.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183343400-d1c01a30-dcfc-4f9e-99a2-832d94e97d50.png)

Next push on the Get Policy Id button.��

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18091631/183343442-431aea82-137c-4fdb-a59b-ca90997c6af3.png)

Copy the Script policy id to be used in your metadata file.

**Metadata File Definition**

Now that we have all information we can define the metadata file to mint the Cardano Native
Token via the Kuber Playground.
The prepared json for the minting with metadata is
```json
{
  "mint": [
    {
      "script": {
        "keyHash": "64b1b102380752d1f1d16b86e77129c68b69a97cb684b1dd5a0fe8df",
        "type": "sig"
      },
      "amount": {
        "Kuber token": 1
      }
    }
  ],
  "metadata": {
    "721": {
      "81feeaef115857f5b7ef9eed00f3b2966b8450258b6080304cd6afc5": {
        "4b7562657220746f6b656e": {
          "name": "Kuber token",
          "image": "https://ipfs.infure.io/ipfs/QmYNeud6Qci8jkWCJYoVHXojvt8e4pBXDhB7UDncSE8Lvi",
          "description": "Kuber token minted from Kuber playground",
          "mediaType": "image/png"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}
```

We copy the above metadata file definition into the Kuber playground and press on Create
Tx with Nami in the left top corner of the Kuber playground which will make Kuber interact
with Nami where name will notify you to sign the transaction.

Once this is done your Cardano Native token should show up in your Nami wallet under the
collectibles image in the middle of your Nami wallet.

Without Kuber making a transaction in Cardano is a four-step process via the cardano-cli

We need to build a transaction with 0 fees, for that we have to create a new transaction file
with a .raw extension. This is used to calculate the fee of the transaction.

  1. Then we use the file and the blockchain protocol parameters to calculate our fees.
  2. Then we create the transaction again but this time including the correct fee. Since we
     send it to ourselves the output needs to be the number of our funds in the UTXO
     minus the calculated fee.
  3. And last, sign the transaction and submit it.

The Kuber library integrated in the Kuber playground eliminates and takes care of all these 4
steps behind the scene where step 4 is handled by integrating with the Nami web wallet.

### **Part 2 - Placing token on sell using kuber playground**

Here the address is a simple marketplace contract address
The simple contract is located on 
https://github.com/dQuadrant/cardano-marketplace/blob/main/marketplace-plutus/Plutus/Contracts/V1/SimpleMarketplace.hs
and it's contract address is

```
addr_test1wqsewsqrurhxer8wx598p7naf9mmcwhr2jchkq6srtf78hctj0p2r
```

Then the value to be locked in the contract is placed as 2 Ada + Token i want to put on sell.
With the datum generated from Plutus Data Used in the contract. You can generate the script data format for cardano using Plutus which is currently out of scope for this tutorial. Anyways the datum used in this contract defines the seller address to be paid and price of the asset. The Data format used in the given contract above.
```haskell
data SimpleSale=SimpleSale{
    sellerAddress:: Address, 
    priceOfAsset:: Integer  -- price of the asset in lovelace
  } deriving(Show,Generic)

```
So the final transaction builder json for placing on sell using kuber will be :
```json
{
    "outputs": [
        {
            "address": "addr_test1wqsewsqrurhxer8wx598p7naf9mmcwhr2jchkq6srtf78hctj0p2r",
            "value": "2A + 5cded5f924b5f029d95918ef5026a737ff6be56daac2667d3aa43c67.mytoken",
            "datum":{"fields":[{"fields":[{"fields":[{"bytes":"570d3e0ae4c913fb3d791a62dcb04b3fbdf03c9cc9fdae966b788db5"}],"constructor":0},{"fields":[],"constructor":1}],"constructor":0},{"int":2000000}],"constructor":0}
        }
    ]
}
```

### **Part 3 - Buying token placed on sell using kuber playground**
1. Sample script json for the contract above
```json
{
    "type": "PlutusScriptV2",
    "description": "",
    "cborHex": ""
}
```
2. Find out the input of previous sell transaction
3. Get previous datum
4. Use redeemer for buy - sample script data for redeemer
```json
{
    "fields": [],
    "constructor": 0
}
```
5. Build output for transferring the cost to the seller
```json
{
    "address": "addr_test1qq3nr3rngpd0uxe5mlypvnc3ayg0ps56v9t5rpjjej9sd250kew3mfvytehnlda2k2v7c4upv4jqjn9pfr7j9a826n2q0mdh8u",
    "value": "2Ada"
}
```
6. So the final transaction builder json for buying the nft using kuber will be :
```json
{
    "outputs": [
        {
            "address": "addr_test1vr6eutuz24n6eu49ymufe37wg89nls5w88j46zju09zuvfskhqmtk",
            "value": "2Ada"
        }
    ],
    "inputs": [
        {
            "utxo": "0e7bb4d01d7c9bca5ded73501a1bf1415ebf005efe6500d2f4a59b3299e5ab27#0",
            "script": {
                "type": "PlutusScriptV2",
                "description": "",
                "cborHex": ""
            },
            "redeemer": {
                "fields": [],
                "constructor": 0
            },
            "datum":{
                "constructor":0,
                "fields":[
                    {"constructor":0,"fields":[{"constructor":0,"fields":[{"bytes":"f59e2f825567acf2a526f89cc7ce41cb3fc28e39e55d0a5c7945c626"}]},{"constructor":1,"fields":[]}]},
                    {"int":2000000}]}
        }
    ]
}
```
